title: BIOL.7210 - Special Problems in Biology
text:
There are three sections of Special Problems running this semester:

Setting yourself up for experimental success
Application and interpretation of linear mixed effects models
Co-Evolutionary Dynamics

“Setting yourself up for experimental success” will focus on some of the fundamental skills needed by anyone doing empirical research. We will discuss key aspects of a rigorous experimental design, how to set up a digital infrastructure for a project, and some basic principles of statistical analyses. This section will end with a session for presenting and brainstorming experimental designs for your own work (or at least something related to your research interests).
“Application and interpretation of linear mixed effects models” will focus on how experimental data is analyzed using mixed effects models in R. We will cover some of the conceptual basis for these models, but will focus on the more practical applied aspects of how these models are used and interpreted. This section will end with a session for presentations on examples of mixed effects models from the literature.
Dr. Nikea Ulrich is running the third section - please reach out directly to her if you’re interested in that section as well.

title: Syllabus
text:
University Resources
Student Mental Health and Well-being
Your personal health and well-being are important to all of us at the university. I’m available to talk about your stresses or concerns related to your coursework in my class.
Here are some resources to support your well-being:








Service/Office
Description
Contact Info


Counseling Services
Provides crisis intervention, assessment, referrals, short term individual counseling and group therapy.
(978) 934-6800


UMatter2
University-wide initiative to support students and promote mental health. Includes access to Togetherall peer-to-peer platform.
(978) 934-6671


CLASS Advising
Provides advising services including goal setting, course selection, SIS functions, changing majors/minors and course deletions.
(978) 934-2936
Advisement@uml.edu


Office of Student Life & Well-being
Advances holistic student success through health-promoting actions and collaboration into campus culture.
(978) 934-4342
Wellbeing@uml.edu



Disability Services
If you are registered with Disability Services and will require course accommodations, please notify me via the Accommodate request process as soon as possible so that we might make appropriate arrangements. It is important that we connect to discuss the logistics of your accommodations; please speak to me during office hours or privately after class as I respect and want to protect your privacy. If you need further information or need to register for academic accommodations, please visit the Disability Services Website.
Inclusion and Classroom Community Standards
UMass Lowell - and your professor - value the many forms of human experiences and backgrounds. Enrich yourself by practicing respect in your interactions, and enrich one another by sharing your point of view, knowing that differences will be respected, appreciated, and recognized as a source of strength.
The Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA) supports and advocates for students while leading programs, workshops, and events that foster understanding, equity, and belonging across campus. Students are encouraged to connect with OMA staff for support, to learn about cultural and identity-based student organizations, and to participate in community-building opportunities. Contact (978) 934-4336 or Multicultural_Affairs@uml.edu
Academic Integrity Policy
All students are advised that there is a University policy regarding academic integrity. Academic honesty is essential to maintaining trust in the learning environment and ensuring that all students are evaluated fairly. Students are responsible for the honest completion and representation of their work, and academic dishonesty in any form will not be tolerated. Acts such as plagiarism, cheating, fabrication, or facilitating dishonesty undermine the integrity of the academic community and may result in disciplinary action, up to and including failure of the assignment or course, and referral to the provost’s office and suspension or dismissal in the case of multiple infractions.
We prioritize academic integrity and the authentic demonstration of students’ knowledge and skills. Consequently, the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools, including but not limited to generative technologies and similar platforms, is strictly prohibited in completing any coursework, assignments, quizzes, exams or any other form of assessment in this course.
Violations of this policy will be considered academic misconduct and will be subject to disciplinary actions in line with the university’s Academic Integrity procedures.
This approach is taken to maintain a fair and equitable learning environment and to encourage the development of critical thinking, problem-solving and academic writing skills without reliance on AI-generated content.
Cell Phones and Other Devices
Cell phone, tablet, and laptop usage in this class is permitted, so long as it course related and does not interfere with other students’ ability to engage in the course activities.
University Privacy Statement
UMass Lowell recognizes the importance of mutual trust between students and faculty. Massachusetts is a two-party consent state, which means it is illegal to record someone without their permission. Recordings of classroom lectures are the intellectual property of the instructor. Instructors have the right to prohibit audio and video recording of their lectures, unless the requesting student is registered with Disabilities Services and recording of class sessions is an approved accommodation. In addition, sharing or selling recordings of classroom activities, discussions or lectures with any other person or medium without permission of the instructor is prohibited, and may result in sanctions for academic dishonesty or referral to the dean’s or provost’s office.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Expectations
I expect you to come prepared to discuss the readings. Paper discussions will ideally be largely student-driven, with my role being more to provide guidance, context, and clarifications. I recommend you come prepared to discuss the content of the papers, including questions and disagreements with the material. I also recommend you spend time reflecting on if/how the subject matter relates to your own work.
These mini-courses should be heavily discussion-based. I expect you all to participate during discussions - I will not be keeping a tally of how often you speak up, but you should make a good faith effort to contribute as much as possible. As mentioned above, these contributions may include questions, opinions, summaries, etc.
I expect everyone to be respectful during discussions. Try to be aware of how you are engaging during discussions - avoid talking over other people and monopolizing the conversation.
Many of the papers may be from outside your area of study - please come at these with an open mind. As some of you may know, my background is in ecology and evolution. The papers reflect this. While the exact methods, techniques, and approaches we use to wrangle with our data may differ from what is standard in other disciplines (especially as we start getting into the statistical components of these mini-courses), part of the critical thinking exercise of this course will be to find the areas of overlap. That being said, places where the disciplines don’t overlap provide opportunities to think about mechanistic or structural differences between fields - these discussions can often be interesting and enlightening, and I encourage you not to shy away from these.

title: Syllabus
text:
Grading
Course grades are based entirely on active participation during meetings. Active participation may look different for each of you - but at a minimum, I expect you to come prepared (i.e. having read and reflected on the assigned readings) and participate in the discussions. There will be no graded assignments, quizzes, or exams.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
These mini-courses provide an opportunity to explore a topic. Given the short duration and broad scope, they can only serve as an introduction. Nonetheless, my goal is to provide enough context for you to think critically about if/how these concepts, practices, techniques, etc. might be applied to your own work.

title: Syllabus
text:
Absence Policy
Please let me know as far in advance as possible if you are going to miss a meeting. Virtual participation (i.e. via Zoom) will not be regularly available. An excused absence will not negatively affect your grade, but if you are going to miss more than one session, I suggest you consider dropping the course.

title: Project Analysis Plan
text: This document should be used to outline the analysis plan for a project. It is most useful for this to be completed in full before a project is officially started, but may benefit from information obtained during preliminary trials.

title: Project Analysis Plan
text: This document should be used to outline the analysis plan for a project. It is most useful for this to be completed in full before a project is officially started, but may benefit from information obtained during preliminary trials.

title: Project Analysis Plan
text:
Questions, Objectives, Hypotheses
This section should list all of the questions and objectives for the project. Remember to keep them SMART:

Specific
Measurable
Assignable (who’s going to do the work?)
Realistic
Time-bounded

It is also helpful to number the questions / objectives.

title: Project Analysis Plan
text:
Variable Descriptions













Variable Name
Variable Description
Response or Explanatory?
Relevant Question or Objective
Data Type
Units
Expected Range
How are zeros and missing data recorded?




Short but descriptive name
Thorough description of the variable
AKA dependent or independent
Which of the stated research questions or objectives is this related to?
Numeric, categorical, ordinal factor, etc.
Units values are recorded in
If known - can be approximate
Important - no empty cells in the data files

title: Project Analysis Plan
text:
Study Design
This section should provide a detailed description of the study design. In addition to protocols and methodological details, this section should include a detailed accounting of replication and sample sizes.
Consider including a schematic or diagram. This could be an embedded image, or an encoded diagram (e.g. Quarto includes native support for mermaid diagrams).

title: Project Analysis Plan
text:
Statistics

Data Processing
You may need to ‘clean’ the data after collection. This section should describe (and explain the utility of) any planned transformations, filtering, etc.


Key Summary Statistics
This section will typically be short. What are the main summary statistics of interest (e.g. mean and standard error, coefficient of variation, etc.), and for which groups will you calculate these values?


Statistical Tests of Hypotheses
The main statistics section will outline the statistical analyses planned and how they will be interpreted to test the stated hypotheses. This includes tests of assumptions, how model fit will be evaluated, any post-hoc tests that could be needed, etc. This section should also include a brief description of any non-standard analyses, and any caveats or expected places where caution will be warranted when interpreting or extrapolating the results. Throughout this section, it is critical that the analyses described are clearly linked to the questions and hypotheses proposed above.
This section should also describe how missing values will be handled. If planned analyses are robust to missing values, state that in this section - it can be helpful to have a reminder of this after data is collected.


Alternative Approaches
This section should outline potential alternative approaches that could be needed (e.g. when assumptions of planned analyses are not met).

title: Project Analysis Plan
text:
Key Figures
This section is relatively speculative. It can, however, be helpful to have a section where you outline the expected tables and figures that might be important to display based on the planned questions, analyses, hypotheses, etc.
